title: FirstFT: Florida passes bill to strip Disney of special tax status
text:
How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz.

Florida lawmakers yesterday voted to revoke Walt Disney's decades-old ability to govern the area around the Walt Disney World theme park in a move seen as retaliation from the Republican state governor Ron DeSantis over the media company's criticism of his administration's LGBTQ policies.

One of the largest employers in Florida, Disney has enjoyed privileges in the state since 1967 that gave it autonomy over water, roads, emergency services and permitting on roughly 25,000 acres near the city of Orlando. It even had the ability to issue its own municipal bonds.

The dispute between Florida's governor and one of the state's most prominent companies centres on a piece of legislation critics dubbed the “Don't Say Gay” law.

The bill, which would ban schools in Florida from discussing sexual orientation and gender identity with children aged nine and younger, faced opposition from Disney's LGBTQ staff who called on chief executive Bob Chapek to oppose it.

After a public relations crisis Chapek, who took over from Bob Iger at the beginning of the year, issued an apology to staff for not doing more to oppose the bill and suspended Disney's political donations to DeSantis and other backers of the bill.

DeSantis, who is facing re-election this year and is believed to be considering a 2024 run for the White House, has since denounced Disney as a “woke” corporation.

The bill will now go to DeSantis for a final signature before passing into law ending the Reedy Creek Improvement District, as the Disney special tax district is known, by June 2023.

Thanks for all your comments about Netflix. Please email any feedback about this newsletter to firstft@ft.com. Here's the rest of the day's news — Gordon

The latest from the war in Ukraine

  • Business: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the brewer of Budweiser and Stella Artois, is in discussions to sell its stake in a Russian joint venture to its Turkish partner.

  • Sanctions: As Russia comes under increasing pressure, western policymakers are assessing North Korean sanctions evasion — in particular China's role in alleviating economic pressure.

  • Sinking of the Moskva: Sailors' families are seeking answers over the sinking of Russia's flagship while Moscow seeks to control the narrative.

  • Interview: Vladimir Putin will renew attacks on “symbolic” Kyiv, the capital's mayor Vitali Klitschko has warned.

  • Oleg Tinkov: The banking tycoon is the highest-profile Russian entrepreneur to criticise Putin's “crazy war”.

  • Opinion: Heavy weapons and more far-reaching sanctions would help end the war, writes Ukrainian prime minister Denys Shmyhal.

  • Video: The FT examines why it took Russia's invasion of Ukraine to highlight London's role in the recycling of Russian money.

Five more stories in the news

1. Elon Musk unveils $46.5bn financing package for Twitter bid The billionaire has lined up $25.5bn in debt — including a margin loan of $12.5bn against his Tesla shares — from banks led by Morgan Stanley. He also said he would provide $21bn of equity for what would be one of the largest leveraged buyouts in history.

  • Analysis: Musk's bid has exposed the social media company's chequered performance.

2. Jay Powell signals Fed is prepared to raise rates by a half-point in May The Federal Reserve chair sent his strongest signal yet that the US central bank is prepared to raise interest rates by half a percentage point at its next meeting in May. Markets are pricing in three half-point rate rises for the next three policy meetings leading up to July and a federal funds rate of 2.77 per cent by the end of the year.

3. French prosecutors issue arrest warrant for Carlos Ghosn French prosecutors have issued an international arrest warrant for Carlos Ghosn and four people linked to an Omani auto dealer. The warrants were issued against Ghosn, who was the architect of Renault's alliance with Nissan, and the current owners and former managers of Suhail Bahwan Automobiles.

4. Rising US rates and China's slowdown hit renminbi China's renminbi is heading for its biggest weekly drop since before the pandemic as the country's deteriorating economic outlook and rising returns on US debt undermine the draw of Chinese securities. The pound has dropped to its weakest level since late 2020 today after the release of weak retail sales data.

5. UK prepares law to give ministers power to tear up N Ireland trade deal The UK government is preparing legislation that will give ministers sweeping powers to tear up the post-Brexit deal governing trade in Northern Ireland. The move is expected to spark anger in Brussels and EU capitals. Sign-up for the latest on Brexit in our weekly newsletter.

The days ahead

Company earnings American Express is expected to give more information today about its decision to suspend business operations in Russia and Belarus when it reports first-quarter results. Verizon Communications and oilfield services company Schlumberger also report earnings.

Economic data Retail spending in Canada is expected to have declined 0.1 per cent in February compared to a month earlier. Preliminary estimates showed a 0.5 per cent month-over-month fall compared to a 3.2 per cent rise in January, according to Trading Economics.

Digital Services Act The EU is to unveil a new law to force Big Tech companies to police illegal content and keep users safe online. The Digital Services Act is the biggest overhaul of the EU's laws governing the world's biggest technology companies for more than two decades.

New Delhi visits Boris Johnson will offer increased defence co-operation to Narendra Modi during talks in New Delhi today, in a bid to break India's reliance on Russian weaponry. European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen will visit New Delhi on Sunday amid simmering anxiety over India's relations with Russia. More details in Europe Express.

French presidential election It is the last day of campaigning in the French presidential election. Voters go to the polls on Sunday to decide whether to give president Emmanuel Macron a second five-year term or entrust the presidency to his far right opponent Marine Le Pen. The latest polls suggest the incumbent will repeat his victory of 2017, albeit with a narrower margin.

  • Are the French ingouvernables as the former president Charles de Gaulle suggested. Sudhir Hazareesingh writes on France's long battle between order and decent in this essay for the Weekend section.

What else we're reading

Will women change the future of management? Office temperatures — mostly set at levels that suit men — are a tiny reflection of a larger truth: women have left a minimal imprint on the “official” theory and practice of management. Are the demographics of work and business due for an overhaul?

Few galleries are selling NFTs despite the hype According to online sales platform Artsy's 2022 Gallery Insights report, only 11 per cent of galleries sold NFTs in 2021, while 67 per cent said their clients had not even asked about them. Of those that did sell NFTs, half said their total sales value was $5,000 or less.

The fun way to predict the unpredictable Games can help us predict future crises that we never knew were possible, writes Tim Harford, from global pandemics to wars and how they pan out. Games are fun, too, making their lessons that much easier to learn.

Global demographic trends create tough choices Richer countries that welcome and successfully integrate migrants will be able to smooth many of the financial pressures of ageing. Others will try to offer financial incentives to increase birth rates, even though they have scant evidence of their effectiveness. Cultural change to make lives easier for parents, especially mothers, will also be needed, writes Chris Giles. This is the latest in our series on how the pandemic affected population growth.
